Problem:
Consider a setup where a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) evolves over time in accordance to two linear systems \\( \\dot{x} = Px \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = Qy \\), with P and Q being constant matrices. The impact of the transformation \\( g(z) = e^{Rt}z \\), where R is another constant matrix, is examined.

If the transformation \\( g(z) \\) is applied to a complex vector \\( z_0 = x_0 + iy_0 \\) at t = 0, and then the system is allowed to evolve under \\(\\dot{x} = Px\\) and \\(\\dot{y} = Qy\\) without further intervention, will \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved under \\(\\dot{x} = Px\\) and \\(\\dot{y} = Qy\\) to t = T?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(z) \\) alters the initial condition of the system by scaling the vector, and thus, the trajectory in the combined system will be affected based on how the matrix R interacts with P and Q, leading to a different state at time T.
